Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Computational Science for Undergraduate Research Experience (CSURE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Computational Science for Undergraduate Research Experience (CSURE) REU Site project will allow a group of undergraduate students to explore and apply computational science models and techniques to an array of data- and computation-intensive scientific questions, using the supercomputers at the National Institute for Computational Sciences (NICS). This project will prepare the participating students for the demanding task of running scientific codes on a scale beyond thousands of processing units. To ensure cutting-edge science, CSURE will partner with teams of scientists at the UT/ORNL Joint Institute for Computational Sciences, who are working at the forefront of computational research in the areas of mathematics, chemistry, biology, physics, and engineering. To broaden participation, CSURE will partner with smaller regional colleges and with Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), to recruit students who would benefit from access to computational resources beyond the capacities of their home campuses.

The CSURE program focuses on five different scientific domains: chemistry and material sciences, systems biology, engineering mechanics, atmospheric sciences, and parallel solvers on emergent platforms. The program for each summer will start with a two-week intensive introduction to the supercomputing environment and to the core computational methods and tools in that summer's focus area. Each student will then be assigned a project appropriate for his or her background and skill level, and will be encouraged to work on the project's salient computational modeling problems, under the supervision of a team of mentors and advisors. Activities will include individual and collaborative computational analysis, meetings and discussions with project personnel, group presentations and feedback sessions, attendance at research seminars, and a final report and public presentation.

CSURE will provide scientific adventure and discovery to undergraduates from a range of science domains, unified by a coherent intellectual focus on scientific computing. Integrating the expertise of faculty researchers and scientific computing specialists, this program will enable each undergraduate to conduct meaningful original research, through the use of supercomputing tools to investigate current significant research problems. The key mission of this program is to convey the importance of computational science and supercomputer infrasatructure for scientific discovery and innovation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Computational Science for Undergraduate Research Experiences (CSURE) was a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site program organized by the Joint Institute for Computational Sciences (JICS). The main goal of the CSURE project was to direct a group of undergraduate students to explore the emergent computational science models and techniques proven to work in a number of data and compute intensive applications using the supercomputers at the National Institute for Computational Sciences (NICS). NICS is an NSF funded program managed by the Joint Institute for Computational Sciences (JICS).

CSURE provided scientific adventure and discovery to undergraduates in scientific domains with a coherent intellectual focus on parallel computing. This program empowered each CSURE student the ability to conduct research using the knowledge of computational sciences in five major domain sciences: chemistry and materials sciences, systems biology, engineering mechanics, atmospheric sciences, and parallel solvers on emergent platforms.

The CSURE program drew the computational sciences expertise of NICS and the experiences accumulated over a decade from our collaborative summer program for students with the Chinese University of Hong Kong under the direction of Dr. Kwai Wong. The CSURE goal promoted the ability of undergraduate students to succeed in a research-oriented program in computational sciences. The program presented the participants a good knowledge of how a graduate project was organized and executed. Hence, the CSURE program tried to mimic the pace and intensity of graduate-level or industrial-level projects with well-defined deliverable deadlines. Its intellectual focus was to push for fruitful research outcomes, in addition to exposing the students to research experiences through appropriate levels of motivations and accomplishments. The program also provided strong professional development, post-program development opportunities, and social networking for the REU participants among themselves. Students were encouraged to continue their research activities at their home institutions afterward. There were five major tasks that the students were asked to follow. Those tasks started with a preliminary lecture presentation and a poster presentation in the mid session and concluded with an open lecture presentation, a final poster presentation, and a final report in the last week. Those tasks aimed to gradually assist the students towards finishing their research goals in time. A detailed listing of the CSURE program is available at the webpage, www.jics.utk.edu/csure-reu.

The CSURE program had 37 scientific research projects. CSURE enrolled 32 domestic students and 20 international students from 2013-2016. Twenty-five domestic students have graduated and 18 of them have entered graduate school. Out of all 52 participants, there were 15 women and 8 minority Americans. The outcomes of the students’ research work are (i) eight conference poster presentations, one of them invited poster presentation at the Grace Hopper Conference; (ii) five conference papers and one journal paper; (iii) continuation of research work at Morehouse College, Maryville College, Alma College, and University of North Carolina, Ashville. The CSURE program had students from 20 different colleges and a total of 40 mentors from 8 collaborative institutes. In addition, Morehouse College in Atlanta has established its HPC pilot program because of this program.

The CSURE program intended to expose participants with a similar level of effort as in graduate school. In four summers, we had resolved many problems and met even more challenges. In particular, the following items summarize the highlights of the program:

  • A well-defined step-by-step timeline leading to the end of the program was in place in early December.
  • The participants were selected based on three major factors: the nature of their home college, their interests and background, and their letters of intent and references.
  • The project assignments were sent to students ahead of time.
  • The first deliverable, a preliminary presentation of the research topic and the approaches of the research, was very important. 
  • Housing for students had to be prepared in the early stage of the program. The entire group stayed together in the arranged housing to get them to blend together socially.
  • Co-locating all students and helpers in a multi-purpose lecturing room enhanced the cohesiveness of the program.
  • A list of safety reminders, health concerns, and emergency contact information was discussed in detail in the first day.
  • A local student was assigned to serve as the site lead to the group, particularly for social activities.
  • Each student began drafting a research plan under the direction of his/her mentor and keeps a weekly research summary log. 
  • A detailed checkout list for each student and a meeting with each student before the program ends were needed.
  • Surveys for the students were performed at the start of the program and at the end of the program.
